content: i honestly don't know how i've been doing terrain videos on youtube for five
years and never done one on lava terrain
hey guys welcome back to black magic craft lava terrain
it is such a classic theme for terrain it's so impactful on the table and it
works great in both war games and rpgs
like you can make a big board of hellish lava terrain and it will be equally
useful for something like warhammer 40k or age of sigmar as it
will be for something like dungeons and dragons the
sponsor for this week's video is crippled god foundry and they just
launched a really cool kickstarter called shattered hell that is packed
full of demonic miniatures for tabletop games
like this dude i painted up one of the demons previously and he now
commands a legion of nurgle demons in my 40k
army but this time around i was inspired by
this big hellish bad boy right here this is a really cool model
and i really wanted to paint him because i've never done a big
flaming demon model before sure some flame elements on minis but
not something like this and i was pretty proud of my paint job on him i'd like to
at some point build a big battle board in this kind of
hellish lava theme but i've never made
any before or painted lava tiles before so i thought it would be prudent to make
a couple test tiles now if you are a game master and you run
a lot of rpgs tiles might be exactly what you need or
want so these will be good as is they're easy to transport they're
easy to store they're modular but if you want to do a
big battle area well the principles are going to be the same
you just build it on a big area instead of a small area i painted one
with cheap acrylic craft paint and a brush and the other i used model paint
and an airbrush can you tell which one is which
i did this both for myself to learn what worked best
when i eventually move into a bigger project but also to prove that you know
you don't have to be limited by the tools that you have available i
started with six inch by six inch squares of half inch insulation
foam if you're struggling cutting perfect squares of the foam i have an
old video focused just on that that you should check out
it's going to help you out now this substrate could be anything but
foam is really quick and easy to cut for the cracked earth
i opted to use cork this stuff is pretty easy to find and generally pretty cheap
i grabbed these packs at dollarama for only a couple bucks the nice thing
about cork is that you can just rip it and get
really great looking edges and it has a really nice natural texture built
right in that will work really well for painting but it's also completely flat
which makes it really good for playing with
miniatures sure you could use something else or enhance the texture with sand
and glue but then you always face that issue of an uneven playing surface
in my first prototype tile i used hot glue to attach random pieces of broken
cork to the foam creating crags which would later become
streams of magma the most efficient way to do this is to
just run the pieces wild go over the edges as you can easily cut
them flush afterwards if you're doing tiles i wouldn't worry
too much about making these crevices line up sure it looks good in theory
when they do but it also looks fine when they don't
and personally i think that if you make them always line up from the exact same
point on every side it creates patterns that look way too
uniform and unnatural so just don't bother for the lava itself
you're gonna want some texture and acrylic latex caulking is a great
candidate for this as it's really cheap accepts paint really well and is pretty
easy to work with i diluted a bit with water and worked it into the cracks
this proved quite difficult to get into certain
areas and nearly impossible to not get all over the surface of the cork
while trying to blend out the mess that i made on the edges i figured i might as
well try coating the entire surface of the cork just to see how the caulking in
combination with the cork worked for a finished surface i applied it as thinly
as possible in order to preserve the natural texture of the cork
at this point i had an epiphany why hot glue the cork to the tiles and then
awkwardly try to fill it in with the caulking
why not kill two birds with one stone why not just use the caulking
as the adhesive so i grabbed a scrap piece of foam to test this idea i
covered the whole surface in undiluted caulking and used a brush to
stipple on some quick texture then i just pushed the pieces of cork in
where i wanted them this was so much easier faster and
way better looking it allowed for far more texture in the lava areas and
required very minimal cleanup with a brush since
i had that extra test piece i broke out my mod podge and black paint mixture and
gave the cork a coating in that this way i could compare which worked better for
the surface the mod podge or the caulking with this
new much better method i created two new tiles on which to test
the two painting styles once dry i found that the mod podge made
the cork significantly harder than the caulking
and it retained more of the natural texture it was the clear
and undisputed winner but before we jump into painting the tiles i want to take a
second to tell you about the sponsor of this video

miniatures and stl files for at home printing
whatever way you like to build your collection
there will be an option for you these models are of course great for tabletop

proxies for various war games the physical minis are hand cast in
resin and from my experience working with many of their models over
the years these casts are clean and detailed they require very little

the resin they use is really flexible and durable so you don't really need to
worry about the models dropping and breaking like you

if you want to get these minis the kickstarter will be the best place to do

i really love the work crippled god does and every time i work with one of their
models it's an absolute pleasure so be sure to
check out the campaign there will be a link in the video
description you can use thank you so much crippled god
for sponsoring and inspiring this video now for the painting this is where the
experiment really gets interesting i've never painted lava terrain before
this was my first time and on a quick browse of youtube it
seems like there's hundreds of videos about painting lavatory
each with their own unique approach since there were so many options
i decided to ignore all of them and just wing it i wanted the stone to be really
dark so i gave everything a coating in flat black craft
paint then i moved directly into an off-white no grays or anything just an
ivory or kind of creamish color dry brushed over the entire tile
essentially i'm mimicking the way i often paint basic mini bases
then a wash on many bases i do the same simple
cream dry brush over black followed by a wash and egg racks earth shade
but of course i'm not going to be using expensive citadel wash on big terrain so
instead i just use a homemade brown wash i've also got a video showing you how to
make this wash and its recipe and all that
you can check that out if you need i really love the way this simple
three stage paint looks and i think it's perfect for hellish tiles
the little bit of red in the brown wash lends itself well to a fiery hellscape
for the lava three cheap as you're gonna get craft paints
with the red i selected one that was a little more on the orange end of red
instead of like a blood red i watered this down significantly and brushed it
over the lava areas the thin paint helps avoid making too
much of a mess on the surface of the tiles
as you can go in with a damp paper towel and dab off the excess mess
this will just leave a thin tint that almost mimics the overspray of an
airbrush it took a second coating before i could
move on to the orange and this was applied in the same way
with multiple thin coats the hardest part is getting
all the texture of the cork edges sufficiently covered without getting too
much on the surface of the tiles and it probably took about four coats
before i got the orange opaque enough to move onto the yellow
yellow was simply a repeat of the last steps but
this time i focused more on the center of the lava to try and make it
blend from yellow to orange to reddish orange with the brightest most yellow
areas being in the center this worked really well but took many
many coats to get good coverage seriously it was slow
to help sell the idea of glowing hot lava i highlighted the hardest edges of
the cork with orange and followed that by a
very minimal highlighting of the sharpest edges with yellow
i finished off the tile with a second coat of brown wash to kind of slightly
filter some of the reds and oranges that kind of got too
much onto the surface of the tile i must admit this came out a lot better
than i expected considering it was my first time painting lava
and it was done with the cheapest craft paint you can buy
with only a paintbrush for airbrushing the stone was painted in the same way
and three similar vallejo game colors were selected
all of the paints were thinned about 50 with airbrush thinner and had a drop of
flow improver added starting with the red i realized that
the orange red i selected was far more on the orange spectrum once applied
than i anticipated rather than switching to get a different
red i proceeded so that i could see if that affected the outcome much versus
the hand-painted tile that had a far truer red applied as the
first coat the difference between applying the
coats with an airbrush versus a paintbrush
is staggering it took far fewer coats to get good coverage
the coats were faster to apply and there was no waiting around for previous coats
to dry before moving on i cannot stress how big of a difference
there was with efficiency here i could keep working continuously from
one coat to the next because the thin coats of airbrush paint dried so much
faster i did have to be mindful of overspray
but a little bit on the edges looked good for a glowing effect
anyway and overall it was easier to be tidy with the airbrush than it was with
the paintbrush i would estimate that i applied all the
coats of colors with the airbrush in the same amount of time it took me to apply
the probably first two coats of red by hand
to finish it off i did move back to the paintbrush to do the same edge highlight
i did with the first one as well as the same
second wash i've made it very clear that the airbrush was
far more efficient but are the results better
honestly i'm not sure both look pretty similar
even side by side while not identical they're not
drastically different i might even argue that at a distance the hand-painted ones
look better and have a better glowing effect
actually that's not a maybe i really like the hand-painted ones more
up close they have their shortcomings but viewed from a normal gaming distance
they straight up look better they look hotter
more believable now some of this i think is
due to the fact that my base coat was a truer red on this one
which i think looks better on the edges of the cork and creates a more realistic
molten look so if i end up doing a much bigger board
in this theme i'm going to have a pretty difficult time deciding
which method i'm going to use you know the airbrush is
far more practical and faster so i probably will go that route but i'll
definitely be mindful of the red that i choose
i think this really proves that you can do
similar paint jobs on this with a paintbrush or an airbrush so
don't be limited by the fact that you maybe don't have an airbrush thinking
about that if i do a huge board i'm gonna have a difficult time
airbrushing it because it won't fit in my spray booth
and that means i gotta spray outside and here we're moving into winter and
outside painting season is about to be over like
today i'm curious to know which one you guys think looks better
or if you think there even is a big difference
